GO.description: The Gene Ontology: a major bioinformatics initiative to unify the representation of gene and gene product attributes across all species.

SBO.description: The System Biology Ontology: used to introduce a layer of semantic information into the standard description of a model, or to annotate the results of biochemical experiments in order to facilitate their efficient reuse.

BTO.description: Brenda Tissue Ontology: provides terms, classifications, and definitions of tissues, organs, anatomical structures, plant parts, cell cultures, cell types, and cell lines of organisms from all taxonomic groups (animals, plants, fungis, protozoon) as enzyme sources.

ECO.description: Evidence and Conclusion Ontology: terms (classes) that describe types of evidence and assertion methods. ECO terms are used in the process of biocuration to capture the evidence that supports biological assertions.

Taxonomy.description: urated classification and nomenclature for all of the organisms in the public sequence NCBI databases

Compounds.description: molecular entities focused on ‘small’ chemical compounds. The term ‘molecular entity’ refers to any constitutionally or isotopically distinct atom, molecule, ion, ion pair, radical, radical ion, complex, conformer, etc., identifiable as a separately distinguishable entity.

Enzymes.description: resource that comprises molecular and biochemical information on enzymes that have been classified by the IUBMB. Every classified enzyme is characterized with respect to its catalyzed biochemical reaction. Kinetic properties of the corresponding reactants (that is, substrates and products) are described in detail

Reactions.description: resource of biochemical reactions designed for the annotation of enzymes and genome-scale metabolic networks and models
